there is an issue with the accessible pedestrian signals at the intersection of 4th st and grand ave in san rafael for the nw ne and sw corners the aps units for both the 4th st crossing and the grand ave crossing are located on the same pole for example i ve attached a photo of the nw corner in this photo you can see that if you are crossing 4th st the audible message from the aps is played next to where you are standing however if you are crossing grand ave the aps message is played about 10 feet behind you and is not loud enough to be heard i am submitting this on behalf of an individual with a visual impairment who lives within two blocks of this intersection and uses it regularly people with visual impairments must wait at the curb edge in preparation for their crossing because the audible message cannot be heard at this distance the functionality of the aps unit is reduced and the crossing is less accessible to people with visual impairments if the aps message was louder or the unit was closer to the crossing point it could resolve this issue

if you walk up from the trail head and take the path to the right you will see the area in the photo just before the short trail dead ends it appears that someone possibly kids setting up makeshift mountain biking structures or perhaps individuals establishing a temporary encampment have been constructing ramps and tying ropes around trees in this area this raises several safety and liability concerns the terrain is steep and unstable making it extremely unsafe for biking or other recreational structures if it is an encampment there is an elevated fire risk we had a fire in this same area a few years ago that originated from a homeless encampment from a liability perspective if someone is seriously injured on city property there is potential exposure to claims against the city given these risks we wanted to bring this to your attention as soon as possible so the city can assess and determine any appropriate next steps to ensure public safety and protect the property

email msg rec d from resident 2 3 2023 there is no specail place to report rough sidewalks so i used the pot hole report but am repeating it in the general report just in case that was not useful except that i cannot upload images wednesday 2 1 202 at about 3pm while walking home from a meeting downtown my wife sherna tripped on a rough bit of pavement on mission st near the union st intersection falling forward onto her outstretched hands fracturing the 5th metacarpal bone and dislocating the 4th finger at the second joint on her right hand and fracturing the distal radius bone in her left wrist a neighbor on the scene called 911 and within seconds the paramedics from the fire station a few hundred meters away was on the scene evaluating her and calling me to let me know when i got there a minute or two later they were splinting both wrists and arms when we got her to the kaiser er the adrenalin was wearing off and she was having a vagal dilation response to the trauma causing her heart rate and blood pressure to drop so she was wheeled into an er room and put on heart and blood pressure monitoring and a drip line installed her vital signs recovered quickly as the doctor was called who snapped her finger back into position and ordered x rays followed by the installations of a cast from her elbow to fingers on the left hand and a cast from her fingers to below the wrist on the right arm i have photos of the side walk and the spot of blood from the small cut on her left hand on one of the flagstones of the entry to 304 union st which has probably washed off now after last night s heavy rain

dear mayor colin and city departments i am writing to report a serious and escalating public health hazard along the jean and john starkweather walking trail specifically the segment behind bahia elementary school near the entrance exit adjacent to 375 and 345 catalina boulevard i live in the senior and disabled housing complex at 375 catalina blvd the slope behind our fence part of the city s easement has become a dumping ground since the city removed all trash cans from this trail years ago the area has accumulated over 1 000 bags of dog feces many ruptured and leaking the stench is overwhelming flies swarm the area liquor bottles and general trash are everywhere this is not just unsightly it is dangerous the portion of the trail behind 375 and 345 catalina blvd is the most severely impacted the slope is grotesque fly infested and reeks of feces and decay mere feet from our homes it is unconscionable to expect private property managers to shoulder the burden of maintaining a public trail easement that the city has abandoned i am demanding immediate action emergency cleanup of the slope and trail segment behind bahia elementary installation of tamper proof locked trash cans especially at the trail entrance near 375 catalina blvd ongoing maintenance and waste collection to prevent recurrence clear signage reminding trail users to dispose of waste responsibly this is a matter of public health environmental safety and basic human dignity seniors and disabled residents should not be forced to live next to a festering pile of feces and garbage the city must take responsibility for its infrastructure and restore sanitation services to this trail segment immediately i urge you to treat this as the emergency it is and respond promptly dear bcdc permit staff i am writing to report a severe and escalating environmental hazard along the jean and john starkweather shoreline trail in san rafael specifically the segment behind bahia elementary school near the entrance adjacent to 375 and 345 catalina boulevard i reside at 375 catalina blvd a senior and disabled housing complex directly bordering the trail the slope behind our fence part of the city s easement and within proximity to bay adjacent marshland has become a grotesque dumping ground since the city removed all trash receptacles years ago the area has accumulated over 1 000 bags of dog feces many ruptured and leaking the stench is overwhelming flies swarm the area liquor bottles and general refuse litter the slope this is not just unsightly it is a public health and environmental emergency the impacted segment lies within the shoreline zone and appears to fall under bcdc s jurisdiction for public access shoreline protection and ecological stewardship the trail segment behind 375 and 345 catalina blvd is fly infested reeking of decay and mere feet from vulnerable residents it borders marshland and contributes directly to shoreline degradation i respectfully urge bcdc to investigate this matter and if within your purview compel the city of san rafael to take immediate corrective action emergency cleanup of the slope and shoreline trail segment installation of tamper proof locked waste receptacles especially near 375 catalina blvd ongoing maintenance and waste collection to prevent recurrence clear signage reminding trail users of waste disposal responsibilities this situation violates the spirit of public shoreline access and environmental stewardship seniors and disabled residents should not be forced to live beside a festering pile of waste on a neglected shoreline trail i ask bcdc to treat this as the emergency it is and help restore dignity safety and ecological integrity to this segment of the bay trail bcdc has replied and they have opened up an investigation kate collins our mayor replied mayor kate 4 26 pm 4 hours ago to me recreation code public i am so sorry to learn about this disgusting situation and appreciate your email i m wondering if it would be possible for you to submit this through the city s online report tool the link is here i appreciate you wanting this to be addressed and the best way to have this request reviewed by city staff is through that link also known as see click fix once you make a report you will be kept updated as the request moves through the city system it is the same way that i report issues that i see in the city as it s the most effective and efficient it also enables city staff to monitor any hot spot areas so they can be proactively addressed in the future warmly kate kate colin she her hers mayor city of san rafael

hello this is mo from 165 oakview drive apn 010 011 49 i previously opened a ticket regarding the required setback for the ephemeral drainage on our property we have now received our biological report from wra which indicates the presence of an ephemeral feature on the property the firm suggests a 15 foot setback from this feature however the report states that this feature variably meets the definition of a creek or drainageway leaving the exact setback unclear our plan set is completed and has been submitted to the planning department for approval during the design process as we were guildeless we were unaware of the specific setback requirements and as a result unit 3 intersects with the setback suggested by wra i need clarification on whether this setback is necessary and the exact required distance i couldn t upload the entire report but here is the relevant text regarding the setback the subject parcel contains an ephemeral drainageway creek that is a potential waters of the state and or u s subject to the jurisdiction of the regional water quality control board rwcb california department of fish and wildlife cdfw and u s army corps of engineers corps the feature was completely dry during the time of the site visit and it does not contain riparian vegetation however the feature variably meets the definition of drainageway and creek per the city of san rafael zoning code per city of san rafael zoning code section 14 16 080 creeks and other watercourses 15 development setbacks for creeks shall be 25 from the top of bank drainageway setbacks can be less than 25 as long as they meet criteria to demonstrate that the resource is protected creek and drainageway are defined in the code as creek means a perennial intermittent or ephemeral open watercourse which has a defined bed and bank and connect to other water bodies as shown on the san rafael general plan watershed and creeks map creek also includes unmapped tributaries to the bay to the point at which they have a defined bed and bank creek is distinguishable from a drainageway drainageway means 1 an open swale or localized depression that lacks defined banks which transports stormwater to creeks wetlands or water bodies such as the bay and 2 man made open ditches or channels typically with low habitat value which drain developed properties drainageway is distinguishable from a creek as described above the feature within the subject parcel starts out as an open swale that lacks defined banks the feature continues downhill to the north and a defined bed and bank and stronger indicators of ephemeral surface flow are present where mapped as an ephemeral drainage a minimum of 15 development setback is recommended and a minimum 25 setback is required where the feature is mapped as an ephemeral creek the ephemeral drainage currently intersects with a portion of the development footprint residence 3 and that portion of the project will need to be redesigned to avoid the email rec d re safety concerns along pathway from anderson to sprouts market to san rafael city public works department san rafael parks recreation department san rafael school district davidson middle school administration dear san rafael city and school district teams as a longtime san rafael resident and community member i want to thank you for your efforts to maintain our shared spaces and keep our neighborhoods safe back at the end of august i reached out regarding the hazardous tree branches coming down behind the homes and near davidson middle school i want to sincerely thank you for your quick response your action was noticed and very much appreciated however there is another issue that has persisted far too long and now needs immediate attention the pathway running from anderson street to sprouts which serves as a main route for students walking to and from school has become unsafe and unsanitary what was once a beautiful tree lined walkway is now cluttered with trash broken glass feces drug paraphernalia and overgrown dry grasses it s being used as a dumping area and the conditions are both unhealthy and disheartening for our community most concerning is that our children your children and grandchildren walk this path every day on their way to and from school they re navigating through unsafe and unsanitary conditions that no student should be exposed to while prior efforts to remove encampments were appreciated the area now requires consistent cleanup maintenance and oversight to prevent this ongoing deterioration i walk that path myself every day and i urge you and our city and school leaders to walk it for yourselves see what our children see each morning and afternoon it s discouraging unsafe and not what our community should accept i respectfully urge the city and school district to work together to restore this pathway clear the debris trim the overgrowth and reintroduce greenery and care it s not just about appearance it s about health safety and pride in our shared community thank you for your time attention and continued commitment to the well being of our students and neighborhoods i m hopeful this concern will receive the same prompt response as before

email rec d re park being used as a training venue dear stewards of san rafael s parks recreation public works i am writing on behalf of a group of gerstle park residents who appreciate and enjoy gerstle park for all that the park represents from a historical perspective and for all that it provides for our local community recently a dog trainer jemzk9 has taken over sections of gerstle park for his personal dog training business on numerous occasions during the mornings and afternoons on weekdays and weekends this gentleman has been observed meeting his clients at gerstle park and then commandeering sections of the park for his private dog training sessions going so far as to instruct other park visitors to steer clear of the area to which he has laid claim and also using the other park visitors without their informed consent as distraction training tools for the dogs he is training as gerstle park is a much beloved public park enjoyed by many in the neighborhood we question whether dog training without proper safety barriers in place is a permitted use of the park especially as there are no public notice boards advising park visitors that dog training sessions may be underway nor are there any means by which park visitors can give informed consent to participate peripherally or otherwise in the dog training generally we believe public parks are to be enjoyed by everyone in the community and therefore should not by virtue of their existence and convenience be allowed to be co opted into private business arenas by private individuals be that for dog training retailing food service or any other commercial activities any thoughts and or actions on this matter would be helpful and appreciated thank you for your consideration

re conversion of one way to two way streets in san rafael d street suggestion for improvement describes conditions where the entry to o reilly automotive parking lot yellow line on attached image is blocked by a vehicle waiting to make a right hand turn i have seen vehicles red line moving along 2nd street preparing to enter o reilly s parking lot but cannot proceed because the way is blocked resulting in d street traffic headed south toward wolf grade also being blocked this effectively blocks all traffic moving across 2nd st green line note that during rush hour there is or can be a long line of vehicles queued up for this turn onto 2nd feel free to project your own experience when you have been in this situation to get a sense of others reaction to it it is true that this condition existed prior to the change from one to two way but the distinction is that now there is more traffic moving across 2nd that can t proceed because the way is blocked whereas before it was not as popular a route to take and while inconvenient it was also infrequent the duration and consequence of the blockage is difficult to model and impossible to describe as it might occur under various traffic loads for example morning rush hour or late night usage so i will not try the importance of d st is that it is used by emergency services specifically the fire department to gain access to gerstel park therefore any delay whether a momentary or full red light cycle is an unnecessary additional danger to human safety serendipitously the screen grab image shows a version of this about to occur but for a different reason then presented above one suggestion would be to add a do not block keep clear or similar instruction in front of the entry to o reilly

regarding manuel t freitas parkway from monticello rd to lea drive and from arlene terrace or iris lane or even sylvia way past lea dr and through to montecillo rd over the years there have been multiple collisions between bicycles and vehicles at freitas pkwy and lea dr there have been at least two fatalities that i know one in 2019 or 2020 and one last saturday 6 28 25 bikers fly down from the open space at the top of frietas past arlene terrace iris lane sylvia way and lea drive often through the four way stop at montecillo i have lived at the meadows of terra linda for almost 20 years so i ve seen this many times and even as a cautious driver i have had near collisions myself due to poor visibility and reckless bike riders while turning left onto lea drive from freitas parkway everyone understands that bikers have the right of way however that is irrelevant if a driver cannot see them due to vegetation or bikers high speeds and dark clothing it is time to prevent further accidents and loss of life my 1st request is for the vegetation that obscures this intersection to be removed entirely not just pruned on an irregular basis this includes the pine tree and bushes my 2nd request is for speed bumps to be placed across frietas from the top of the hill to the bottom near montecillo to slow speeding vehicles and bikers preventing reckless joy rides additionally speed bumps are necessary from montecillo rd leading up to the left turn at lea drive so cars will have to slow down and be able to carefully assess this intersection for pedestrians crossing lea dr or bikes and cars racing down the hill on frietas prior to turning the uploaded image shows the view looking up frietas at the turn onto lea even if a driver is turning slowly and trying to look for bicyclists it could be impossible to see them especially when bikes are traveling at high speeds cars are can also be difficult to see a driver might have their eyes focused to the left looking for pedestrians and completely miss a bike that might then collide with them it is critical for the city to address this as soon as possible everyone in the community can deal with speeds bumps and the loss of the bushes and tree to prevent lives from being lost over and over again i urge the city to take action

email rec d re safety concern 2nd st and nb 101 offramp dear city of san rafael team i serve as the director of education at canal alliance a community based organization located in san rafael i commute daily from san francisco and frequently cross the intersection at 2nd street and the northbound u s 101 offramp near the shell gas station i m writing to report a serious pedestrian safety concern at this intersection vehicles frequently run the red light and make right turns despite the no right turn on red signal i have witnessed numerous near collisions between cars and pedestrians including several instances where i was almost struck while crossing eastbound on 2nd street this intersection presents an immediate danger to pedestrians cyclists and drivers alike i respectfully request that the city consider increased traffic enforcement review of red light camera data or adjustments to signal timing and signage to improve compliance and pedestrian safety thank you for your attention to this important issue i would be happy to provide additional details or speak with a member of your traffic engineering or public safety team to discuss possible solutions

i am writing to you concerning the new signage regarding turning from west end avenue on to second street at marquard ave in your plan you say vehicles from west end ave eastbound can make a right turn only onto marquard ave vehicles on west end ave can access second st through the signalized intersection at greenfield ave and fourth st advanced signage will be installed along greenfield ave to direct vehicles to fourth st for access to second st towards downtown san rafael my husband and i have lived here on spring grove avenue for more than 50 years and have never had a problem merging on to second street from west end avenue although i applaud the safe new bike path i see no reason for traffic not to continue to merge from west end avenue on to second street as it has always done also it makes no sense that vehicles from marquard can use this intersection and vehicles from west end cannot i like the addition of the traffic light as it makes the merger even safer unfortunately over the past several months i have seen many people ignore this signage you ve also created a new problem with directing people to use the lights at greenfield and fourth only one car can safely wait at the light cars come from three directions and bicycles from two directions you have created a new dangerous intersection if you miss the light allowing cars to turn from greenfield to fourth you must wait several minutes thus increasing the blockage in the intersection you have created a new situation that may increase city liability my solution to this problem is to simply remove the signage at marquard and west end along with the speed bump barrier in the street let cars safely merge with the traffic on second street as they have done during the last 50 years i have lived here respectfully submitted janie teitelbaum

email rec d from local business re illegal dumping dear public works team i m writing on behalf of sol food regarding an issue that has persisted for many years the recurring accumulation of trash on the lincoln avenue sidewalk between 3rd and 4th streets specifically in front of the private parking lot just a stone s throw from our restaurant we ve informally dubbed this area the trash vortex due to the volume and variety of debris it routinely collects to highlight the issue we ve compiled photos from over the years on this instagram page feel free to follow and share we understand this stretch of sidewalk falls under the oversight of multiple city agencies which has made coordinated solutions difficult that said a potential fix was discussed during a previous site visit or brainstorming session but unfortunately was never implemented we respectfully ask the city to consider taking the following steps 1 notify the businesses using this section of sidewalk for garbage service that going forward bins must be placed on 4th street instead 2 install a planter or other permanent obstruction along the fence line of the private parking lot to physically deter trash placement in this area we believe these two simple steps could significantly reduce illegal dumping and improve the streetscape for all nearby businesses and residents after nearly a decade of informal maintenance and cleanup efforts on our part we are sincerely asking for the city s support to help close this chapter thank you for your attention and consideration
